greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least positive integer k <= n such that 2^k + (n - k) is prime, or 0 if such an integer k does not exist.
comment: See also part (i) of the conjecture in A231201.
Now we find that a(1657977) = 205494. The prime 2^205494 + (1657977-205494) has 61860 decimal digits. - _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Aug 30 2015
We have found that a(n) > 0 for all n = 1..7292138. For example, a(5120132) = 250851, and the prime 2^250851 + 4869281 has 75514 decimal digits. - _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Nov 16 2015

We have verified that a(n) > 0 for all n = 1..10^7. For example, a(7292139) = 218702 and 2^218702 + (7292139-218702) is a prime of 65836 decimal digits; also a(9302003) = 311468 and the prime 2^311468 + (9302003-311468) has 93762 decimal digits. - _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Jul 28 2016
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Zhi-Wei Sun, Write n = k + m with 2^k + m prime, a message to Number Theory List, Nov. 16, 2013.
Zhi-Wei Sun, On a^n+bn modulo m, arXiv:1312.1166 [math.NT], 2013-2014.
example: a(3) = 2 since 2^1 + (3-1) = 4 is not prime, but 2^2 + (3-2) = 5 is prime.
program: (PARI) a(n) = {for (k = 1, n, if (isprime(2^k+n-k), return (k));); return (0);} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Nov 11 2013
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Nov 11 2013
